From publisher blurb:

A wiry Human woman guns the throttle of a contraband military vessel while navigating through an asteroid field. Her copilot, a round, squat creature with one eye on a long stalk, gleefully fires the ship’s plasma cannon at the pursuing bounty hunters. A gnarled hunk of meteorite lays in the hold. It pulses with the ultraviolet glow of dark matter magic. A vaguely humanoid android snaps a jeweler’s monocle into place on their optical sensor to get a closer look as a feline man takes a wrench to the smoking engine room.

boardgame.name: Pataphysic Wander
boardgame.description:
"Pataphysic Wander è un gioco che parla di adolescenza, di mondi fantastici e del percorso per divenire adulti. Ogni protagonista delle storie di Pataphysic Wander ha subito un trauma che lo porta a fuggire dalla realtà, un dolore che lo allontana dalla vita quotidiana e che potrebbe segnarlo per sempre.
Nel mondo dei sogni ogni protagonista conoscerà altri come lui, affronterà i propri incubi e crescerà o si perderà per sempre.

Questo gioco è un lungo viaggio verso il futuro, verso il riscatto e l'accettazione di sé. Questo gioco non ha presunzione di essere in alcun modo terapeutico o didattico, parta di dolore e lo affronta in modo metaforico, parla di sentimenti e di crescita, come le migliori serie di formazione. Questo gioco può suscitare emozioni intense: se accade, godetevi il momento. Questo gioco serve per raccontare una storia, renderla vostra.

Pataphysic Wander utilizza il regolamento di Fate Accelerato con l'aggiunta e la variazione di alcune regole tutte racchiuse all'interno di questo manuale, per giocare non ti servirà altro che un gruppo di amici pronti a lanciarsi nel mondo dei sogni!"

boardgame.name: Dunqora: Le Cronache delle Guerre Eterne
boardgame.description:
Vi fu un tempo in cui tutto era pace, in cui i popoli di Dunqora non muovevano alla guerra e dove le ballate dei cantastorie non raccontavano di soldati valorosi e madri piangenti.
Vi fu un tempo in cui gli antichi Ein’Sherai abitarono queste terre con rispetto e amore, prosperando in ogni dove. Un tempo in cui i sogni degli uomini erano tutt’uno con le loro vite.
Poi, gli Antichi caddero, persi nell’ombra più oscura delle loro paure e i compagni divennero nemici, gli alleati avversari, gli infanti il germe della futura ribellione.
E la guerra avvolse Dunqora con un manto cremisi, esigendo il suo tributo di sangue e sofferenza. La luce abbandonò questo mondo, ridotta a una flebile piccola speranza.
Ogni popolo anela il potere ghermendolo tra le mani, ma come insegnano gli Antichi, tutto il potere dell’universo non può essere racchiuso in un solo pugno nemmeno dall’Eterno sognatore.
Così sarà, un ciclo infinito di lotte e sofferenza, finché la speranza non verrà ritrovata e la piccola luce non diverrà un fuoco purificatore.
– Estratto da: La Profezia Fulgente di Imnagar -

(from the back of the book)

boardgame.name: 弱者の剣 (Jakusha no Tsurugi)
boardgame.description:
弱者の剣 (Jakusha no Tsurugi, "Sword of the Weak") is the first game from Polygonotes. It resembles the classic card game Daifugo but adds many twists.

At the start of a round each player is dealt six normal cards and one Sword of the Weak card. Normal cards have two numbers on them, one blue and one red, that always add up to nine, as well as a colored symbol in the middle. The Sword of the Weak has a different pattern on the back and its red and blue numbers are both one.

Your goal is to play all your cards. Each turn you have to either pass (and draw a card) or play cards to the middle. In order to play cards to the middle you have to have a higher total than the previous hand, and whether you use the red or blue numbers depends on the Scales card by the deck - it starts on blue, but every time a Sword of the Weak is played it's flipped. Being lucky will help you play larger hands, but in order to win you'll have to correctly time when you play your Sword card for the greatest advantage.

—user summary

boardgame.name: 逆臣の炎 (Gyakushin no Honoo)
boardgame.description:
逆臣の炎 (Gyakushin no Honoo, "Fire of the Rebel") is the second game from Polygonotes. You play as a servant in the house of a mad king, waiting for a chance to depose him to save the kingdom.

The game has three special kinds of cards. There's one each of the Night and the Dawn, which move around the table - the Night is always held by the active player, and the Dawn by the previous player. In the deck there are many "Flames of the Treacherous Retainer" cards, which have different colored backs. A round ends when one player has three Flames and the Night card; you win by having 20 points at the end of a round.

Each turn you can play a card or draw a card. Some cards can't be played and just add points (positive or negative) to your hand. Others have all kinds of effects, like making another player put a Flame on the bottom of the deck, reversing turn order, or even flipping the deck upside down. Even the Night and Dawn cards are worth points, so you might want to trick someone else into ending the hand.

In order to win you'll have to choose when to play your cards right as well as bluff the other players as to how good your hand is. Can you depose the king?

—user summary

boardgame.name: 信濃国土豪衆 (Shinanokoku Dogoushu)
boardgame.description:
信濃国土豪衆 (Shinanokoku Dogoushu, "Lords of Shinano") is a card-laying game about exploring mountainous terrain and choosing the right spot to build a castle.

Each turn you may move and add a card to the map. You can move one step across normal terrain, pay two points to move through mountains, or you can move as far as you want along a river for free. When you add a card it has to be on a space next to your pawn and any rivers must line up. You get points equal to the number on the card (1, 2, or 3, with higher point cards being more complicated) for every edge that perfectly matches what you put it against. If no edges match you can still play the card but it's worth negative points equal to its face value. If you can't play a card at all, you have to discard one face down, which is worth triple negative points at the end of the game.

Once during the game you must play a castle. This costs ten points, but at the end of the game you get points for the card under your castle and the four neighboring cards. Castles must be built at least two cards apart, so building in the right place can also deny other players points. When moving, castles and pawns both allow you charge tolls for anyone passing through, which is the best way to get a point advantage over other players.

Explore the countryside, build your castle in the right place, and see if you can become the richest Lord of Shinano.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Ryuuki no Toga
竜姫の咎
boardgame.description:
竜姫の咎 (Ryuuki no Toga, "The Sin of the Dragon Princess") is a push-your luck engine building game. There are only five days left before the final battle - can you defeat the enemy and become a legendary hero?

Long ago the Dragon Princess broke a taboo and had a child with a human. The "Sin" was a target for all the monsters in the world, and to defend her child the Dragon Princes descended into the Abyss. After an unimaginably long time, the Abyss transformed the Dragon Princess into a monster, and she's coming to reclaim her child and destroy the world in the bargain. You have just five days to defeat her.

Each round has three phases: card acquisition, playing units, and deciding whether to challenge the monster. A number of cards equal to the numbers of players is dealt face-up, and everyone reveals which one they want at the same time. If there are any conflicts, the start player for the round decides how to resolve that, and it doesn't have to be fair. Next you play units that add to your battle strength. Some units can be played for free, but advanced units will require spending mana of right color from weaker units. Finally you decide if you're ready to challenge the monster. You only get to do this once, so you want to wait until you're strong enough, but not so long someone else beats the monster first.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Ostroleka 26 maja 1831: Iganie 1831
boardgame.description:
Iganie 1831 covers the battle of Iganie, one of the most brilliant victories of Poles over Russians during the November Uprising. It was fought between the Polish army commanded by General Ignacy Prądzyński and the Russian 6th Corps commanded by General Grigory Rosen. The battle was the final part of the Polish Spring Offensive. The goal of the operation was Russian army’s main depot in Siedlce, which supplied all Russian forces fighting in the Kingdom of Poland. After two first successful for Poles battles at Wawer and Dębe Wielkie (both on March 31st 1831) the pursuit for the defeated Russians was stopped. It allowed them to control chaos which appeared during the retreat, reorganize their units and bring reinforcements.

The battle of Iganie was the last try to broke Russian 6th Corps near Siedlce and capture the Russian main depot. Planned by General Prądzyński attack of three groups approaching from three different directions failed becaue of the lack of operational coordination and poor command of General Jan Skrzynecki. Two groups which had to cooperate with Prądzyński’s maneuver group did not appear during the battle and has come to the battlefield in the late evening or the next day. This caused that Prądzyński’s forces had to fight outnumbered by Russians. Russian forces also were divided into parts. General Rosen was bound by the orders from Field Marshal Ivan Diebitsch which urged him first of all to defend Siedlce and keep defensive position on the eastern bank of the Muchawiec river. That gave Prądzyński chance to beat the enemy situated on the western bank of the Muchawiec river before Russians combine all their units and destroy his group. The decisive moment of the battle was when Russians started to move battalions from the eastern bank of the Muchawiec river to its western bank where the battle was taking place. Prądzyński decided to seize the only bridge on the river. During terrific bayonet fight Polish 5th Line Infantry Regiment completely broke the elite Russian Jaeger Brigade (13th & 14th Jaeger Regiments), called Warna Lions (because of their fame gained in the recently finished war with Turkey), and captured the bridge. This cut off Russian units on the western bank of the river from the rest of their comrades. Finally Poles won the battle. The Russian losses are estimated between 3 600 – 4 500 soldiers, while Polish one numbered 400 – 500 soldiers. Tactical success of Poles was undoubted, however they did not decide to attack through the swampy river Muchawiec also because of the informations that the main Russian army is near and would join the Rosen’s forces the next day.

The game is an expansion for Ostrołęka 26 maja 1831. It means that Iganie 1831 uses system rules (also charts & tables) and markers which are in Ostrołęka 26 maja 1831. There are two scenarios in the game: the historical and the alternative one. The first one in more detailed way simulates the battle and all background of it, especially specific events and operational situation of both sides. The alternative scenario is more flexible, giving the players more possibilities to create their own strategy and modify the course of the battle. However this scenario also stays in historical frames. Although the game bases on Ostrołęka 26 maja 1831 system rules, there are few new rules for this battle only. The most important are command points and changeable phase order. In the rule & scenario book you will find also a detailed historical article on the battle and some additional system rules for Ostrołęka 26 maja 1831 (especially an integrated table of artillery fire with round-shot and granades). The playing time varies from 2,5 to 4 hours, however there is an autowin option which can end the game faster.

Components (all packed in ziplock):
- One mapsheet 42 x 30 cm
- 108 die-cut counters
- One rulebook and scenariobook (both in one book)
- One sheet with information on Russian artillery modifiers
- Two sheets whit unit rosters (for Poles and Russians)
- One sheet with turn track and command points tracks
- One sheet with mapsheet legenda

boardgame.name: The Everrain: The Under God
boardgame.description:
Description from the Back of the Box;

This expansion introduces The Under God, the architect of the Everrain, to be used as an optional replacement end game boss to the Avatar of The Under God. The Under God comes with its own unique set of Elder One boards, with a host of new dark powers and abilities to combat. From unfathomable depths, the nameless one finally comes to finish its work...

As the Avatar heralds its arrival, it was only a matter of time before the Old One itself arrived on the earth to claim its prize! Upon a great creature it rides, nestled in it's stone throne where it has sat for time immemorial.

The Old One offers a new boss to try and beat when playing the Everrain. The Old One behaves differently than the Avatar and has its own unique objectives to defeat it!

The Old One token begins the game at the end of the Discovery Track, and it represents how close the Avatar is to rising from the sea and destroying the world! Ordinarily this token rarely moves, but if enemies begin to gain the advantage and are allowed to run amok, the token will begin to descend down the track. If the Enemy and Old One tokens ever meet, then the Avatar awakens and appears on the game board!

The Avatar has its own board, which describes the effects that it has on the game. These are things that players must be wary of doing, because each time that the player triggers one of these effects, it brings the Avatar one step closer to arriving in the world.

For players to have a chance at winning, they have to trigger the endgame. This is done in one of 2 ways:

1. Reaching the end of the Discovery track - If players can do this, they have gathered enough knowledge to now attempt to subdue the Avatar. This is known as the Slumbering Objective

2. Defeating the Avatar - If at any point the Avatar is summoned, the end game immediately is triggered and players must defeat it somehow. This is known as the Arisen Objective

In both cases, once the endgame has been triggered the Avatar board is flipped, and the player's objective is revealed

boardgame.name: Taimu toranku man
Time Trunk Man
タイムトランクマン
boardgame.description:
User summary
タイムトランクマン (Time Trunk Man) is a Japanese game of time travel (English rules online - see weblink).

In 22XX, a while passed since operation of time machines began, agents of a private time travel company named "Time Trunk Man" undertook a mission of retrieving lost treasures scattered through ages.

In the game of TIME TRUNK MAN, players travel around past Tokyo (Edo), present Tokyo, and future Tokyo (Neo Tokyo) to retrieve lost treasures.

At the beginning of the game, players place their pawns at a location of their choice in present Tokyo.

During your turn, you play two action cards.
1) Move: Move your pawn up to written number of spaces without changing ages. You may gain resources on the way.
2) Search: Draw a search card and place the written resources at any unoccupied locations in the wriiten age of Tokyo.
3) Time Travel: Spend resources to travel to different age of Tokyo without changing locations.
4) Purchase: Spend resources to purchase a lost treasure at the age you exist.

You draw an action card each time you play an action card.

When any player accumulates 15 points worth of lost treasures or more, the game end after the last player's turn. The player with the most points wins the game.

Publisher's summary
It's the year 22XX, and time machines have been operating for a while at this point.

In Time Trunk Man (タイムトランクマン), players are given a mission to recover valuable relics that have been lost in one of three periods of time: Edo, Tokyo, and Neo-Tokyo. Where? When? That's for you to figure out as an agent of a time-moving company. Be the first player to recover 15 points worth of lost treasures to become the #1 agent!

■ストーリー
タイムマシンの運用が始まってしばらく経った22XX年。
プレイヤーは、民間時間移動企業「タイム・トランクマン」のエージェントとして時間移動をしながら、現代では失われてしまった貴重なロスト・トレジャーを回収するミッションに挑みます。

■ゲーム概要
価値点15点以上のロスト・トレジャーを先に集めたプレイヤーの勝利です。ロスト・トレジャーの購入やタイムトラベルに必要な「動力通貨」、マップ構成の異なる3つの「時代ボード」、プレイヤーの行動を左右する「アクションカード」など、ゲームの戦略をより奥深くするコンポーネントが特徴です。

boardgame.name: Mutants & Marvels 1.0
boardgame.description:
The Superheroic Role-Playing Game

From the introduction:

In 1984, TSR introduced a new Superhero RPG, using the licensed characters and world of the mighty Marvel Comics brand. Suddenly role-players found themselves able to have exciting adventures, taking on the roles of iconic heroes such as the Avengers and all of their members, as well as Spider-Man, Daredevil, and many others. The game was well-received, though it had its share of problems that needed to be “fixed”.

Jump forward to the early 2000’s. Suddenly the Open Gaming License made it easy for anyone to write their own game, and have it instantly playable, using the simple “d20” mechanic.

Mutants & Marvels is an attempt to marry those two ideas, and make it more generic. So, what you have here is an attempt to capture the four-color awesomeness of the old, and infuse it with the streamlined mechanics of the new.

boardgame.name: Open Game License
Open Game License (OGL 1.0a)
boardgame.description:
From Wikipedia:

The Open Game License (OGL) is a public copyright license that may be used by tabletop role-playing game developers to grant permission to modify, copy, and redistribute some of the content designed for their games, notably game mechanics. However, they must share-alike copies and derivative works.

The OGL describes two forms of content:

Open Game Content (or OGC)


...the game mechanic and includes the methods, procedures, processes and routines to the extent such content does not embody the Product Identity and is an enhancement over the prior art and any additional content clearly identified as Open Game Content by the Contributor, and means any work covered by this License, including translations and derivative works under copyright law, but specifically excludes Product Identity....


Product Identity (or PI)


...product and product line names, logos and identifying marks including trade dress; artifacts; creatures characters; stories, storylines, plots, thematic elements, dialogue, incidents, language, artwork, symbols, designs, depictions, likenesses, formats, poses, concepts, themes and graphic, photographic and other visual or audio representations; names and descriptions of characters, spells, enchantments, personalities, teams, personas, likenesses and special abilities; places, locations, environments, creatures, equipment, magical or supernatural abilities or effects, logos, symbols, or graphic designs; and any other trademark or registered trademark...


Use of another company's Product Identity is considered breach of the licensing agreement.

boardgame.name: On Pointe: The Ballet Board Game
boardgame.description:
Experience life as a ballet dancer, from the Barre to a Star. Earn your pointe shoes and tutu; collect gems, treasures and the tiara.

In On Pointe players use dance moves as shown on the deck of cards to move through the game from the first dance studio through rehearsal and eventually to the stage. Players stop at certain intervals in the game to collect gems, which are worth 3 points and treasures, which are worth 2 points.

Each player has a score card where they accumulate the items for later end-of-game scoring. Points are also awarded for landing on the Pas de Deux squares, the Prima Ballerina square where one player will get the tiara and the final stage square for the bouquet and bow.

In addition to the cards, each player has five 'Position Tokens' each of which can only be used once and then is turned over after executing the given 'power-up' move or action.

The player who is positioned last, in relation to the front edge of the stage gets first selection of movement cards shown on the table and play proceeds clock-wise from there. The result of this turn designation is that players tend to travel though the game board fairly closely together.

Since the winner is determined by a calculation of points, arriving first at the end of the stage does not guarantee a win.

On Pointe is a dancer's journey in a board game.

boardgame.name: Dungeons & Dragons 4th Edition System Reference Document
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The SRD that follows these Usage Guidelines is a straightforward list of 4E References, which you may use in your Licensed Product. It also contains blank formatting templates (statblock templates) for presentations such as monster statistics, poison statistics, skill challenges, and so on. These Usage Guidelines also tell you how to use needed material that doesn’t appear as a specific 4E Reference.

You may use any 4E Reference in your Licensed Product, assuming the reader knows or can learn the meaning of that 4E Reference from the Core Rulebooks. Differing forms of a 4E Reference, such as a plural form, are assumed to be part of that 4E Reference. You may use such differing forms as needed to allow a clear exchange of ideas in your Licensed Product.

Use the stat block templates identified and included in the SRD as guidelines (not constraints) for producing your own original content requiring such formatting. Since your content will resemble like content in the Core Rulebooks, it will be more readily usable. You may not reproduce the blank stat block templates included in the SRD in a Licensed Product.

To remain in compliance with the GSL, you may not reproduce any running text, statistics block, or table from the Core Rulebooks, nor may you define, redefine, or alter the definition of any 4E Reference. Nothing in these guidelines should be taken as contrary to these GSL requirements.

boardgame.name: 300: Earth & Water
300: Earth and Water
300: Erde & Wasser
300: Greco-Persian Wars
300: La Terre et L'Eau
300: Terra e Acqua
300: Tierra y agua
boardgame.description:
In 500 BC, Ionia rebelled against Persia's rule and Greece supported it. With this "foreign interference" as an excuse, the Persian empire decided to invade Greece. In 492 BC the Persian forces attacked Macedonia from land and sea. The Persians and the Greeks fought fiercely at Marathon, Thermopylae, and Salamis. Against the overwhelming forces of the Persian empire, the Greeks used superior tactics and "weapons" such as hoplites (heavy infantry) and triremes. The Greeks had also excellent leaders in times of crises and eventually prevailed over the Persians.

300: Greco-Persian Wars is a wargame for two players. One player controls the Greeks, gathered around the Athenians, and the other controls the Persians, fighting for the hegemony of the eastern Mediterranean. Through all five expeditions, each player aims to control more cities than their opponent.

The game engine is a "card driven" system. Players raise armies and buy cards during production. Cards can be used to play an event or move an army or fleet. Events can provide advantages in battles or interfere with the enemy, but military action is paramount to win. Moreover, each game will change dramatically according the order the events occur.

The rules are simple and the playing time is short, but both Greece and Persia have a wide range of strategies, so victory will challenge both players.

boardgame.name: d20 System Reference Document (SRD)
System Reference Document
boardgame.description:
From Wikipedia:

The System Reference Document (SRD) was published in 2000 by Wizards of the Coast and is based on Dungeons & Dragons (3rd Edition); it was revised following the release of Dungeons & Dragons (3.5 Edition), in 2003. The SRD allows for third-party publishers to freely produce material compatible with D&D. It also forms the basis for independent role-playing games from other publishers, such as Mutants & Masterminds and Pathfinder Roleplaying Game (1st Edition), among others.

User summary:

The SRD (3.0) originally was offered as a series of eight topically organized RTF files that collectively constituted the entire document.

The Revised SRD (3.5) originally was offered as a series of eighty-six topically organized RTF files that collectively constituted the entire document. The original download page also included the option to download seven topically grouped ZIP archives or a single ZIP archive - these archives contained the same content.

Both the original and the revised SRD often were accompanied by supplemental files, such as the OGL, licensing materials, and introductory guides. These materials were not considered part of the SRD.

Numerous online - usually HTML - conversions have also been produced by, de facto licensed, 3rd parties.
boardgame.rpgseries: Wizards of the Coast Open Game License and System Reference Documents

In Dragon Sword werden die Schauspieler mit einer jahrtausende alten Mumie konfrontiert, die beim Ausbau der U-Bahn-Strecke von Kowloon nach Hong Kong Island entdeckt wird. Als Schüler der Li-Wong-Kampfschule müssen sie dabei ihrem vorbestimmten Schicksal ins Auge schauen.

Das Abenteuer ist in der Neuzeit angelegt und ist ein reiner Martial-Arts-Film mit Wuxia-Elementen. Er wurde inspiriert von dem Hong-Kong-Film „Iceman Cometh” und dem koreanischen Film „Arahan”. Die Spielzeit des Abenteuers liegt bei etwa 8 Stunden.

In “Chopsticks and Dropkicks” arbeiten die Schauspieler im Restaurant Tasty Tiger Noodles. Eines Nachts werden sie unfreiwillig in einen Handel zwischen dubiosen Gästen verwickelt. Die Schauspieler erwartet ein Abenteuer mit irrwitzigen Situationen und überraschenden Wendungen. Der Film spielt im Jahr 1993 und ist ein Comedy-Martial-Arts-Film. In „37th Chamber of Shaolin“ sind die Schauspieler Schüler in einer kleinen Kung-Fu-Schule. Eine alte Fehde entfacht aufs Neue, und die Schauspieler müssen sich auf eine lange und beschwerliche Reise zu einem mystischem Ort begeben. boardgame.name: Moogic
boardgame.description:
Moogic is a strategy card game capturing the thrill of competitive cattle farming. Building and running an economically viable farm will require the skillful management of resources as well as the strategic deployment and timely slaughter of cattle for income. Along the way you will also raise revenue by milking your cows, breeding cattle and sending your herd to graze on both your own and your opponent's farm, all while attempting to defend your own patch of grass from your similarly inclined neighbor.

Players have a hand of cards from which they play farmland, cattle, action, enrichment, and building cards. Farmland cards are free to play and produce grass which can be spent to play other cards. Any unspent grass can be grazed on by your opponent's cattle to earn money. Money can also be earned by milking cows or slaughtering cattle. Action and enrichment cards directly affect the player or other cards in play. The winner is the first player to earn 100 coins.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Core Worlds: Empires
boardgame.description:
Six empires have risen from the ashes of the Galactic Realm. Still cemented by the alliance that enabled their unprecedented conquest of the galaxy, the six independent kingdoms now seek to consolidate their power, each hoping to carve out the strongest dominion in the cosmos. Conflicts among the young realms are inevitable, but will the galaxy return to a state of civil war?

Core Worlds: Empires is a worker placement game for 1 - 5 players that includes rules for Solo Play. Each player represents one of the empires that overthrew the ancient Galactic Realm during the original Core Worlds card game. Core Worlds: Empires is a thematic sequel to the original game and its expansions, but players don’t need to own the original game to enjoy this one.

Each world in the galaxy occupies a board space that an empire’s ambassadors can visit during the game. The worlds that appear during each game are variable. Each player starts with a certain number of Imperial Worlds under his or her control, including one of the coveted Core Worlds that lie near the center of the galaxy. Neutral Worlds that have recently recovered from the civil war enter the game as play proceeds, and players may visit these worlds or attempt to annex them to their empires.

boardgame.name: UniQuest
boardgame.description:
A game for unicorn lovers. A magical game of unicorns that is simple and fun for all. Get the most unicards by matching mane color, hoof color, and horn color to the unicard you wish.

Players have a hand of 5 cards. Most cards have a unicorn on them with a colored mane, hooves, or horn in one of the 7 colors of the rainbow. Cards are also marked with a shape to help differentiate colors and for help with the colorblind.

During a turn, a player draws a card from the top of the deck or the discard pile. Once a player has three matching color unicorn cards of all three types (hooves, horn, and mane) they may discard all three and claim that color Unicard.

Unicards are separate from the cards used in the deck and player hands. There are 7 Unicards, one for each of the colors of the rainbow, and the first player to claim 4 Unicards wins the game. But be careful, because other players can steal your UniCards by also matching the same colors.

Also included are rainbow unicorns that can be used as any color and the dark horse which prevents you from winning.

—user summary

FanTan
boardgame.description:
Description from App Store:

If you would like to play Fan-tan, you can play by this game. The design is for those who want to play with pictures of cards in pure form. Number of player is 4 people.(You and Three computers)

- Rule of Fan Tan
1. First, after to begin game, 4 people get each 13 cards.
2. Next, put number 7 on central(It starts automatically).
3. After that, It starts from the person who put the number 7 of diamond on central.
4. Then, put a card next to number of central card (If 7 card on central, you have to put number 6 or 8 card)
5. Finally, ranking is decided when put all cards from each person.

You can pass if you can't put card next to card of central. The number of times which can be passed is decided by a basic rule, but it's possible to decide the number of times by this game than setting. If you passed the number of times by fixed, you lose and put all cards on central.

You gain the KP(Point for game) by ranking of result. If you gain a lot of KP, you can enjoy another way.

- What is another way to enjoy.
When you gain KP you can buy the property(article). Let's buy all them and monopoly.
But, computer buy a property if it has a lot of KP, when you are careless.
You are able to purchase the computer's property but you need a lot of KP.

- How to gain KP.
You can gain KP when you play Fan Tan.
And, this game has stock system, you buy or sell your KP by stock system, it may be possible to gain a lot of KP. The price of stock changes when you play Fan Tan by one.

- Additional information
This game does not have sounds. You can play quietly

boardgame.name: Kunoichi ni Chikai
くのいちにちかい
boardgame.description:
くのいちにちかい (Kunoichi ni Chikai) is a game about ninjas in training. A "kunoichi" is a female ninja, and "kunoichi ni chikai" means "almost a kunoichi" - but you could also read it as "close to the ku". But what's "ku"? It's a little pink token in the box! Use the powers of your kunoichi trainees to move them around in the grid and get closer to the "ku"!

At the start of the game sixteen cards, one for each character, are laid out in a four by four grid. The players are dealt an equal number of cards, each corresponding to one of the ninjas. Each card has a different ability to move cards around, like "swap any card and the one two to the right and one down from it" or "slide any column up, wrapping around". After each player has used all but one of their cards, the last card determines which ninja they get points for, with more points going to ninjas closer to the "ku".

In order to win you'll have to use your powers to rearrange the grid while balancing that with holding on a character in a good position, even if they have good powers. You also have to be careful not to favor any character too obviously as other players can interrupt your plans.

Can you get close to the "ku" and finally become a full kunoichi?

—user summary

So humble is their beginnings, that they may seem to be more of a hindrance to the “real heroes” in the battle against evil. That’s the thing though isn’t it? Is the natural martial acumen of a warrior or inherent magical ability of a wizard what makes a hero a real hero. OR, is it the willingness and determination to put yourself in danger to save a life? Nowhere else is that determination more evident than in the Rook. A hero that starts with nothing, but can be anything.

Included in the book is;

1 brand new class
5 new backgrounds
25 new feats & 2 new bonds!

boardgame.name: Swashbuckler (PBM)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The Glory of Kings PBM/PBEM is very involved and can be an expensive game in which to participate, both in terms of time and money. For God, King & Country was introduced many years ago as a roleplaying variant to allow players to take part as a single character rather than trying to run an entire nation or pirate brotherhood. It ran for a few years reasonably successfully but was then brought to an end. This brand new game, Swashbuckler, has the same basic premise. What then is that premise, I hear you cry?

It's this: Swashbuckler runs within the game world of The Glory of Kings. That means the nations and larger organisations are run by the players of The Glory of Kings, while Swashbuckler players take part as a single character or person, someone further down the social scale with less power but still with a desire to make their mark in the world. The result is that Swashbuckler players can take part but their turns are cheaper, and also faster for them to deal with. So, Swashbuckler is designed to be quick to play and cheaper on your wallet - if you want more, then that’s what The Glory of Kings is for!

This gives the games a unique layer. For example, if you want a commission as an officer in a royal regiment, you will have to write a letter to the king to stand a chance of getting such a lofty appointment. And the king will be another player with different objectives since he is playing in The Glory of Kings in the same world!

Also you'll get caught up in the actions of The Glory of Kings players. For example, if one is committing piracy a ship you are sailing on may be captured, or what if you are staying in a town that comes under siege? The great thing is lots of different people in real life are impacting what happens to your character, the situations he or she finds himself in; it isn't all just down to the whim of the referee!

“It’s called Spontaneous Silly Head Syndrome and it affect fewer than 1 in 7 billion…”

Meet Marlo Davenport.

Marlo was born with a curious case of Spontaneous SIlly Head Syndrome, a rare disorder which makes the individual suffer temporary transformations. How does Marlo cope with such a condition, and is there a cure?

Join Marlo in this one of a kind narrative driven mockumentary style adventure game. Learn about Marlo’s life through compelling monologues, solve fun puzzles to help him overcome his odd condition and figure out just what the heck is happening to him! Not everything is as it seems as you’ll discover unraveling Marlo’s strange story. What happened to Marlo’s father? Who is this Linda he keeps talking about? Why does he keep changing into a slug?

Presented as a low res documentary with fully voice acted talking heads, The Mind of Marlo is best described as an absurd combination of TV show The Office and classic point and click adventure games of old.

boardgame.name: Arena of Eternity
Malkyrs: Arenas of Eternity
boardgame.description:
Malkyrs: Arenas of Eternity is a collectible card game, with elements of role-playing and timing allowed by the use of computers/phones and wireless technology.

Each card contains a RFID chip, which is recognized either by a proprietary reader or a smartphone app, and allows it to keep track of:

its current Health, Might, Intelligence and Strength levels;
its learned Skills;
its Evolutions (by using "Favor" points);


which implies that two physically identical cards can be different in-game depending on their playing history.

The game itself focuses on a main Champion card, which embodies the player as it casts Action cards to bring its oppenent's Health total to 0.
Playing these Actions has an element of timing, as a computer app keeps tracks of player turns, which by default last 30 seconds; some effects can alter this total, or some cards have different effects depending on how soon/late they have been cast.

Each victory grants Glory points, which are tracked by the app, and can be reinvested as Favor points to upgrade cards (see above). The app also allows to play online.

boardgame.name: Trust Me, I'm Psychic
boardgame.description:
Do you believe psychics can glimpse into the future or that all psychics are frauds? The mystical and hysterical game of Trust Me, I'm Psychic might change your thinking!

In this unpredictable game of predictions, one player acts as the Customer, asking a question about their future that the Psychics must answer. All other players act as Psychics, and are dealt a Vision card that tells them if they are a true Psychic or a Fraud. All the players who are true Psychics see the same tarot-inspired image that they can use to craft a fortune for the customer. The Frauds do not see the picture, and will just have to wing it (with some help from the Cursed Words clues on their card)!

The Customer asks a question on any subject about his or her future. Will I win the lottery? Will I find true love this year? Whether you are a Psychic or a Fraud, use your imagination to spin a fantastical fortune for the Customer. Of course, fortune-telling is not as easy as it seems. Psychics and Frauds must avoid speaking the forbidden Cursed Words listed at the bottom of their cards. If your fellow Psychics/Frauds catch you saying a Cursed Word, you'll get a Curse Token.

If you tell a convincing fortune the Customer rewards you with a token and gets to look at your card. If the Customer chose a true Psychic, they can use the image on the card to deduce who the remaining Psychics are. But if the Customer accidentally pays a Fraud, he or she gets a Curse Token.

The game ends after each player has a turn being the Customer. The player with the most money tokens (after subtracting Curse Tokens)wins!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Strongholds & Followers
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

In this book you will find rules for four types of strongholds: keeps help you raise armies and improve your fighting ability, temples help you summon extraplanar allies to aid you in battle, towers let you research new spells, and establishments let you collect secrets and generate cash.

Every stronghold also improves your signature class feature, powering up your Bardic Inspiration or your monk’s Ki. Strongholds grant improved class features because they draw power from the land itself.

The local area around your stronghold is called your demesne (deh-MAIN). Within your demesne, your character is now, if not ruler, certainly a very important person, so the power of the land manifests itself in unusual ways in your favor.

Building a stronghold also inspires people, allowing you to attract followers by rolling on a chart specific to your class. These followers could be mercenary legions or artisan peasants, foreign ambassadors or fellow adventuring heroes!

Large-scale actions taken by your new army, your stronghold, or your followers sometimes take months or seasons. Also, your new abilities eventually run out of juice, after which you must return to your demesne to refresh yourself. This is called an extended rest.

To support these new options, the book comes with many new systems, including rules for warfare, in which units of soldiers clash; rules for concordance, which allows any character to plead with their deity for aid; rules for creating new magic items; and rules for taking your retainers with you into combat without having to run an entire second character.

Se Rappeler, also known as "Fun to Remember" is a box containing the components to play a series of children's memory games:


The Pairs Memory Game - the traditional "Memory" game where players turn over two cards at a time trying to make matched pairs.



The Countryside Game - On a board depicting an outdoor scene, a player arranges several pieces in the empty spaces and shows it to the other player. The first player then secretly changes one or two pieces and shows it again to the other player, who must identify the changes. Players take turns until one has identified ten changes correctly.



Kim's Game - Players take turns being the dealer. They place 20 silhouette pictures on the table, give other players a few seconds to look and then secretly remove one or more. Players then must mark on their board which pieces have been removed, keeping the markers for correct guesses. After each player has been dealer twice, the player with the most markers wins.



What Followed Next? - Players start with a set of eight pictures face-down. The first player chooses a picture, looks at it, says aloud what it is and then places it face-down, starting a row. The second player chooses a second tile, looks and then must say the name of the first and second tiles in order. The third player must name the first two tiles in order and then his or her newly-drawn tile. This continues until a player thinks another has made a mistake and calls for a check. The tiles are checked and whichever player is wrong is eliminated. Play includes until only one player remains.



In the Pocket Game - Each player has a board depicting 20 objects. Silhouette tiles of these objects form a supply. In turn, each player chooses a silhouette and hides it. The player to the left then asks a yes/no question about the item (e.g. "is it round?"). If the answer is no, the next player asks a question. If the answer is yes, the asker may guess the identity of the item. If correct, the player receives the tile and places it in the correct space on his or her board. If incorrect, the next player may take a turn. The player who wins the tile becomes the next to choose a tile and answer questions. The first player to get five tiles wins.


—user summary

boardgame.name: Gusha no Hitsugi
愚者の棺
boardgame.description:
愚者の棺 (Gusha no Hitsugi, "Fool's Casket") is a test-your-luck game from Polygonotes. A band of heroes have found an ancient treasure horde, but before they can take any of the prizes away they'll have to get by the ghosts that haunt it.

Each round you'll try to get a piece of treasure by drawing from the ghost deck. If you draw a ghost with the same element as the treasure you can keep it, but if the fourth ghost of a type comes out it'll play a trick. Exactly what the trick does varies by type, but it includes swapping your treasure with the top of the deck, swapping someone else's treasure, or even flipping the deck upside down.

You can choose what treasure you go after, so will you go for high points, the safe bet, or try to interfere with the other players? You can avoid ghost types that are about to play a trick on you, or you can go after them to trigger the trick on purpose.

The first player to ten points wins the round and escapes the tomb with their treasure - and their life!

—user summary

boardgame.name: Clue Master Detective
boardgame.description:
A decent, but dull, computerized version of a popular Parker Brothers board game of the same name, Clue Master Detective is based on the Master Detective version of Clue that was first released in England.
It is different from the original Clue (or Cluedo) in that this version offers 12 rooms instead of 9, 4 new suspects, and 2 new weapons. The only real differences in game play is that there are now "snoop spaces" which allow players to look at any one of another player's cards. Also, when making suggestions, players don't have to stop after one of the suggested cards is shown to them. Play continues, so it is possible to be shown all three suspected cards in one turn. This makes the game much easier than the original Clue.
In Clue Master Detective the computer game plays exactly like the board game, with the same premise. Dr. Black is found dead, and the object of the game is to discover who killed him, what weapon he/she used, and where he is killed. Each turn, you must move from room to room to make your enquiries. Once inside a room, make a "suggestion" on your turn by calling a character and a weapon into the room. You can then question your fellow players as, one by one, you ask them to reveal if they have a card that matches the room you're in or the character and weapon you've named in your suggestion. Your turn ends when one of these is matched by another player's card. Keep note of your findings and carry on playing. By clever deduction, you'll eventually be ready to make an accusation.
The only appeal that Clue Master Detective may have to fans of the board game is the fact that you can play against the computer if nobody is around (although up to 10 people can play the game together in hot-seat mode). The game does record notes for you though, which is a plus. Unfortunately, the AI is pretty bad, and you can't change the difficulty level to make the game more challenging. As it stands, Clue Master Detective is recommended only to die-hard fans of the boardgame who want to while away some time while they wait for friends to play the next boardgame session.

boardgame.name: Yuushi no Kusabi
勇士の楔
boardgame.description:
勇士の楔 (Yuushi no Kusabi, "Bonds of the Brave") is about heroes deciding which army to join. You want to be the strongest member of the winning army, but you'll have to find out what the other players are planning while hiding your own intentions.

At the start players are dealt three cards, and four cards are dealt to the middle, two face up and two face down. Each turn you take cards from the middle, put some from your hand back, and then add more cards to the middle from the deck. Once someone has ten points in one color they can announce victory for that team; everyone else gets one chance to announce victory for another color if they also have ten points, and then you move on to scoring. Declaring victory in a color is advantageous but might not be enough to overcome a sneaky player; whoever has the most points total over all victorious colors wins the round. This means that besides winning on the strength of your own hand, you can win by investing in multiple suits other people are stronger in.

The most subtle part of the game is the different kinds of cards. While some cards give a simple color bonus, those are the rarest. The next most common type can count for either of two colors during scoring, but don't count towards the 10 for declaring victory. Most cards are worth few points on their own, but worth more in pairs with specific cards - in particular, the purple color has no invidually strong cards, but is worth the most with the right pair. Each color has its own distribution, and keeping that in mind is key to victory.

Can you read the other players to figure out which color you should throw your lot in with?

—user summary

boardgame.name: Seiryuu no Kanmuri
星竜の冠
boardgame.description:
星竜の冠 (Seiryuu no Kanmuri, "Crown of the Star Dragon") is the third game from Polygonotes. You play adventurers chasing after the precious scales of the Star Dragon; the game is semi-cooperative, with a pure coop mode for 2-3 players and a more competitive mode with the potential for betrayal for 3-4 players.

Each turn has three phases. In the preparation phase, you can spend Stars to buy items or heal, and you choose an item to use in the combat phase. In the combat phase, you flip a card from the Star Dragon deck and resolve its attack. Only the players with the highest attack or defense rating take part in combat. If things go well you can earn Stars here, but if they poorly some players will take damage. Some Dragon cards also have special effects like doing damage to players with too many Stars. Finally, in the Spoils phase the Stars earned in combat are split evenly among all participants. The game ends after ten turns, when the Dragon's Crown is revealed.

Because Stars are used to heal damage as well as to buy the items you attack with every turn, you'll have to balance offense and defence in order to survive the dragon's attacks. If you're playing to win you can play it safe in a round by trying to avoid combat... but since you won't get a share of the spoils that's risky too. You'll need balance in how you deal with the Dragon as well as your allies to come out ahead.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Christmas Miss Givings
boardgame.description:
A fun family friendly game for 4-8 players, ages 10 and up.
It’s Christmas Eve, and you’ve all forgotten to get each other gifts! Now you’ve got a few hours left before the store closes to rush and get some gifts that (hopefully) match each other’s interests and score some points. The most points at the end of the game wins. Just watch out for people being Naughty!

Everyone gets 3 unique interest cards at the start of the game, as well as some fit cards to get started. Each gift has two interest on it, including a few double interest cards, ad each round, players will have to give out a gift. Each match is worth 2 points, and a self match is 1 point.

And then there are Naughty or Nice cards. Naughty cards to things like steal cards and swap gifts, while Nice cards help out the other players, but score 1 point. There are also Block cards, which will stop the other Naughty and Nice cards, and can score points if used to block Naughty cards.

—description from the publisher

This game has officially been announced by the publisher or developer, and remains in development. Therefore, some of the game information may change in the future. Until this game is released, please do not submit images for it, nor add new releases. Press Kits are an exception.




Ancient Cities is a survival and strategy city builder based on ancient times.

Starting in with a nomadic tribe you will have to guide your people through the Neolithic revolution, discovering and improving technologies, managing resources and population, facing enemies, and ultimately, building the most fantastic city of the antiquity.

Main features
All meaningful for gameplay!

Simulated years, seasons, day cycles and weather
Simulated ecosystem where every plant and animal you see is growing, reproducing and dying

Natural disasters

Play your game!

Buildings and resources decay. No more bread lasting for years!

Different factions use trading, fighting and influence to dominate the world.

boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

This is the System Reference Document for 3.5 game mechanics. It includes all documents except psionics and epic levels. It has been organized, edited, and reformatted for ease of use.

This PDF has been optimized for ease of use. Sub-categories and tables are nested below their main bookmarks for quick reference. All tables (except tables appearing directly in spell descriptions) have been named and numbered so they can be quickly selected in the bookmarks.

Hyperlinks have been added to provide quick access to spell descriptions referenced within certain sections, feats that reference special attack moves, and to tables that appear on different pages than the reference.

Where possible, tables have been slightly altered to prevent splitting between pages.

In order to streamline the presentation, some redundancies in words and phrases have been removed.

Sections have been organized for ease of use. For example, prestige classes are listed directly after the standard classes.

This PDF is released under the Open Game License as a free download. You may print this PDF for your own personal use.

Please see the complete license at the end of this PDF for complete information.

boardgame.name: Et sans résultat! Tabletop Rules for Recreating the Napoleonic Wars
boardgame.description:
Et sans résultat! is a grand tactical wargaming for the Napoleonic period.

The grand tactical focus means that a lot of low-level detail is abstracted away, a battalion being represented by a single stand. While this loss of detail may be mourned by some, it allows battles to be fought in a timely manner and players to concentrate on the tasks of generals rahter than of junior officers.

The rules aim to be compatible with figures from 2mm to 28mm size, and almost any basing scheme. There are also boxed sets of 10mm figures from The Wargaming Company purpose-made for the rules for those who don't already have an Napoleonics collection.

The title, French for "And without result!", is from Marshal Ney's comment on the indecisive yet bloody battle of Eylau.

boardgame.name: A Baker's Dozen of Noble Families

Publisher Blurb:

In any fantasy setting that is remotely medieval or feudal in base, noble families wield a great deal of power and are of great importance. They can become patrons, allies or foes of player characters, a source of quests and help or a constant pain in the characters' side. It's useful to have some families that can be dropped into a campaign.

boardgame.name: Cell-O
boardgame.description:
A strategy game for 2-4 people. Cell-O allows players to change their pieces over the course of the game, creating countless combinations of movement possibilities!

In Cell-O, each player starts with a single cell creature which can move, eat, multiply and evolve into slowly-growing shapes that dictate their future movement. Competing against other creatures for food and space, players must try and expand their population enough to escape the primordial pool of their species' birth into the greater world beyond.

During a turn, each player gets one action to move, eat, or spawn a new creature from an existing one. Eating gives a creature a new shape that then dictates how it moves in future. It takes tactics and foresight to mutate and expand your population in order to escape while preventing your opponent's from doing the same.

When a player gets enough of their creatures across the board and out of the pool, they win!

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Storm of Spears
boardgame.description:
Storm of Spears is a set of grand-tactical miniatures wargames rules for Greek hoplite battles of the late fifth and early fourth centuries BC. They also cover contemporary Rome, Etruria, and Carthage.

Despite the grand-tactical scope, the rules allow players to control quite a bit of tactical detail like file spacing and line depth, these being deemed critical to the tactics of the period.

Scenarios are provided for seven historical battles (all Greek), and orders of battle are provided for dozens of further battles and campaigns. The rules allow for troops based on 30, 40, or 60mm frontages.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Port Gdańsk
boardgame.description:
Port Gdańsk has never been so busy! Tens of vessels are calling at the quays, while long arms of port cranes are put in motion high above the ground. Another busy day is starting in the largest Polish port. Dockworkers have their hands full to unload the goods waiting on vessels as fast as possible.

In Port Gdańsk board game you act as a company operating in the Port. Your task is to load and unload goods to make them reach their warehouses or means of transport in the shortest time. Don’t forget about hiring workers and serving the awaiting cruise ships. It’s thanks to them that you’ll gain an advantage over your competition that’s breathing down your neck and you’ll increase your chances of winning. Be fast, first vessels are already calling at the quays!

The game Port Gdańsk consists of a series of player’s turns. In your turn, you roll the dice to determine what kinds of actions you can perform. Available actions: loading, movement, and recruitment. Before or after performing the actions from the dice roll, you can do some additional activities:

Execute one order,
Use exchange panel once,
Serve one cruise ship.


Gather goods, fill in port warehouses executing precious orders and send off your workers to serve the cruise ships!

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Anthelion: Conclave of Power
boardgame.description:
The sun is setting on one of the most devastating battles the Pocket Universe has ever seen. After years of fighting, it is becoming clear that this war will not be won on the strength of military victories alone. The leaders of the Dynasty and the Liberation turn their attention to some of the most influential figures in the galaxy to strengthen their cause.

Who will be able to consolidate their power, gain new allies, and turn old foes to their side? Who can form a Conclave powerful enough to gain control of the Universe?

Anthelion: Conclave of Power is a game for 2 players who choose two unique special character abilities on their turn to manipulate the locations of the characters in play. Players seek to pull characters from all factions, good, evil and neutral to their side of the table (their Conclave), or push unwanted characters to their opponent. The player that can amass ten points of influence by getting enough characters to cross all the way to their side of the table will be declared the winner.

Anthelion: Conclave of Power builds on the foundation of the two-player influence manipulation game Avignon: A Clash of Popes.


Released in the March 2019 Board Game of the Month Club $20+ package.

boardgame.name: Die Fly!
boardgame.description:
Die Fly! is a 2-6 player card game where each player will take their turn by playing a card onto one of two discard piles. Most of the cards in the deck are flies. When a discard pile has some flies in it any player out of turn can play a fly swatter card. When playing a fly swatter card on one of the discard piles that player then collects all of the cards in that piles. The more flies you kill the more points you are awarded at the end. There are other cards that allow you to steal from another player hand or from another players kill pile (the bug zapper, and frog cards). The spider allows you to kill two flies directly out of your hand. The food cards allows you to name a type of fly and any player that has that type in their hand must give you all of those flies. You can't forget the poop card when played forces the opponents to place a fly directly on it, but also when someone uses a fly swatter card on a pile that has a poop card that player must complete a penalty to continue on the game.

The theme is based off of flies, butterflies, and dragonflies. The art is goofy but totally fits with the style of play. It is a fun family friendly game that only takes about 15 minutes to play.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Herd: Fleece Your Friends
boardgame.description:
Herd: Fleece Your Friends is a competitive card game where luck and skill are equal partners on the path to victory. So, grab your crook and let's go! In Herd, you are obsessed with one thing: creating the greatest herds in the land. Score points by acquiring geep, a half-goat half-sheep hybrid, and organizing them into herds. Protect your herds from marauding wolves, but if a wolf emerges from the hills you can send it to devour the herd of another player.

Players are dealt a hand of three cards to start the game. During their turn, players begin by drawing a card from the draw pile. Four options are then available: Form a herd, play a wolf on another player's herd, play a specialty card, or allow the next player to go. A player scores points by forming herds using three geep cards of the appropriate colors. Herd: Fleece your Friends is played in rounds. A round ends after one of the players plays her last card and has nothing else in her hand. Other players have one final turn. At the end of the round, the point values of the player's herds are totaled and the point value of the cards remaining in the player's hand are subtracted from this total. This is the player's score for the round. The player with the highest total wins a victory token. The first player to collect three victory tokens is the winner of the game!

—description from the publisher
